title: Planned 24-hour blackout completely illegal: PUCSL
body_lines: COLOMBO (News 1st); The Chairman of the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka, Janaka Rathnayake says that the planned 24-hour blackout was completely illegal, and action will be taken against the Ceylon Electricity Board Engineers Union with regard to the power cut which was was due to take place in parallel with the union strike action.

The supply of electricity for several areas was hampered following an outage experienced across multiple districts in Sri Lanka. which included Colombo, Kandy, Trincomalee, Mahiyanganaya, Hatton, Anuradhapura, Ratmalana, Moratuwa, Ja-Ela, Kotte, and Dehiwala.

Power outages were experienced from 4 AM to 8 AM in the morning, however was restored following the Ceylon Electricity Board Engineers Union decision to call off the strike after discussions with the President.
The PUCSL Chairman said that there is no grounds for a power outage to take place in context of electricity being made an essential service.

Therefore, he said that regular power outages for 2 hours and 15 minutes will take place according to the published schedule, and the power cuts which took place today morning have been deemed illegal.

Neither the CEB unions nor the CEB engineers have any right to cut off electricity, the PUCSL Chairman emphasized, pointing out that the Chairman of the CEB trade union had planned a 24 hour blackout, out of his mandate.

Those who committed this crime this could face up to five years in prison with up to five years of hard labor, along with a fine between Rs. 2000 and Rs. 5000 on the wrongdoers, the PUCSL Chairman warned.
